. @wKovacs64 the registering happens in the Iconics class which is now part of the core. Prior v1.5.x the Iconics included the GoogleMaterial, FontAwesome fonts in it's constructor. So they were added automatically, and you only had to register additional fonts. 
The registering is only required if you try to use the fonts via xml or programmatically via string (when you want to create the icon via the string name). I somehow have to find out the font class by the 3 char identifier --> "gmd" --> via the Iconics font map --> GoogleMaterial.class
I have not found yet that a class is automatically instantiated and it will register itself. (as far as i've found this is not possible), then i tried to have it via pre processor annotations, but this was not possible as this works only when i have only one module. 
I do not want compile time annotations as those will lower the performance. 
Perhaps i can go a similar approach as with the AboutLibraries, to define the fonts via xml in the resources, and i will then just try to instantiate the class via reflection and add it to the map of registered fonts. should be possible, but i would have hopped for a better solution for this problem :/

. Hi. 
The problem is that you have a version conflict with the Android-Iconics included in the Materialdrawer and the latest available version of Android-Iconics. 
With v4.0.0 of the MaterialDrawer i will include the latest version of Android-Iconics. Until you update you have to go with the older version of Android-Iconics. or you exclude the Android-Iconics dependency from the MaterialDrawer.
A version which is compatible is this one: https://github.com/mikepenz/Android-Iconics/tree/88e9d0279f4248cbe20016b72763198c35ab4bae

MaterialDrawer v4.0.0 rc12 contains the iconics-core v1.7.1

. @powerhcm8 that works sure. But you will have some additional effort just to see it in that editor. . @toyongbanatero you can't use this on a canvas. It seems you mix up a few things. 
There are 2 different things the iconics library does / or can do:
- Icons within text (of TextView, Buttons, etc...) - 
  In this case the Iconics-library uses a SpannableString and replaces the {cmd-star} with the unicode character used to identify the specific icon in the iconfont, and sets a TypefaceSpanable on it. So it switches the font for the exact position and then this font is drawn as icon as the unicode char matches to this one
- Icons as Drawable - 
  The other function is that the Iconics-library can create Drawables under the hood it uses a similar mechanism to draw the icon instead of normal text. (A bit more complex as it was optimized for performance...) In theory it creates a path out of the specific unicode char (specified via the  {cmd-star} notation) in the specific typeface and draws it. 
In your case i think you will have to draw the text. and then also draw the {cmd-star} icon as bitmap (you can create a bitmap out of the IconicsDrawable

. @pperliti ok just debugged it via the sample. The issue is that if you use the automatic detecing of fonts within a RecyclerView that it reuses the fields and this causes an inconsistent state as it switches out everything very fast. 
To be able to automatically also replace the placeholders with an icon if you set the text, the IconicsFactory registers an addTextChangedListener which will fire if the text is changes. This is to takes a short time, also the modification of the string and replacing with the icon. Which can cause your described exception.
As far as my debugging shows I don't think this can be prevented inside the editable replacing. 
You can easily fix this if you directly set the icon within the adapter with the following code:
java
view.setText(Iconics.style(ctx, new SpannableString("{faw-hospital-o}")));

. @MarkOSullivan94 ok the issue is really easy to fix. :D And not related to the library. 
You use the wrong url for the app namespace, because you already had the card_view namespace defined. 
By default Android studio will define the res-auto url, if this was already defined it will use the tools url. If the tools url is used android studio is happy but will remove the defined xml properties during the build. 
To fix your issue just remove the card_view namespace. Change the app namespace to:
xml
xmlns:app="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res-auto"
and change the card_view:card* definitions  to app:card*

The reason why i limited it to 3 characters is that the icons can be used via xml too and in other locations too. When I resolve it there I will always check if a id is 3 characters long, if it's longer or shorter I will ignore it and go on. It is done like this for performance, and other optimizations. 
Just use a 3 character ID ;). There are enough possible combinations still available with 3 characters ;)

The issue is caused by the following:
WIth the IconicsLayoutInflater2 I'll automatically replace text with the icon + attach a text listener to the textview. 
When we then adjust the text the normal draw logic instantly kicks in of the textview, during this time we get the event of the TextWatcher with the editable, which we modify to be the icon. 
The problem here is though, that the draw logic of the TextView is too stupid and does not detect that instead of multiple lines (the text for the icon would result in 4 lines) is now only 1 line (the icon is super short, the text behind is also super short, so no line break necessary) So it will blow up. There's sadly not much we can do about this (setting the lines, and line number to 1 surprisingly does not change the internal line calculation :D)
The easiest approach to get around this is use the IconicsTextView as this will adjust the icon during setText, another approach (but not so handy) would be to apply the styling to the text as spannable, and apply this then to the normal TextView (so it would have the short string from the beginning) 
Another nice workaround is to add android:ellipsize="start" to that TextView as this will change the way it calculates line breaks, and it won't crash anymore. . @zwieback did you try to give the icon a color and a size?. @zwieback there are rare cases where it's fine to have no size. that's why it is not an requirement.

Basically this code just checks the included ressources and tries to detect the fonts which are available:
https://github.com/mikepenz/Android-Iconics/blob/develop/library-core/src/main/java/com/mikepenz/iconics/utils/GenericsUtil.java#L52
. well I assume that in such a case the auto registering of fonts won't work. 
So adding a try catch won't solve it for you. There is a new release needed allowing you to manually register your font you want to use, and after that mark the init as done. so that it won't try this code block over and over again. otherwise you will end up in an endless loop. So in v3.0.3 I added a new method for you :)
First register the font you want, via the registerFont method. 
And then markInitDone. So it won't hit the reflection based auto detection anymore:
https://github.com/mikepenz/Android-Iconics/blob/94c247dedf8f15649ab6986a023444c95655dd00/app/src/main/java/com/mikepenz/iconics/sample/CustomApplication.java#L27
https://github.com/mikepenz/Android-Iconics/blob/94c247dedf8f15649ab6986a023444c95655dd00/library-core/src/main/java/com/mikepenz/iconics/Iconics.java#L91. Just pushed to maven central. might take ~15-30 minutes for it to be available. @Aqua-Ye no init() required at all. So basically init() usually does the reflection based check to retrieve the fonts based on their string contained (was the best way to make it detect a module) 
https://github.com/mikepenz/Android-Iconics/blob/develop/library-core/src/main/java/com/mikepenz/iconics/Iconics.java#L52
So the RegisterFont basically does it manually, and the markInitDone() finishes the init step :)

fennifith:
@MFlisar a way to solve this would be to use the following settings on the icon:
sizeDp - 56
paddingDp - 8
iconOffsetXDp - 4
The problem with the icon is that it's only centered by the sides of the icon and doesn't take into account the actual proportions. Since more of the icon is to the left of it's actual center, it makes it look like the center is slightly to the left of where it really is. The offset of 4dp fixes that problem, but an option for the library to measure the size of the icon and change the offset accordingly would be nice.

Hi 
I did not have success with using DrawableCompat.  I believe it is for compatibility with pre-v21 devices (which I am not testing on) and that on v21+ devices it just passes the call through to the underlying drawable. 
setTintList and setTintMode are both empty implementations in the base drawable class as it is up to drawable itself to implement it appropriately.
https://github.com/android/platform_frameworks_base/blob/master/graphics/java/android/graphics/drawable/Drawable.java#L568
As Iconics is dealing with vector data the best reference would be the Android VectorDrawable implementation.
https://android.googlesource.com/platform/frameworks/base/+/eb034fb/graphics/java/android/graphics/drawable/VectorDrawable.java#212
There is a updateTintFilter function provided in the base Drawable that may be useful.

ade:
Ok, I can see that now. However, I do not believe that prevents potential users from getting confused, as the project readme, the generator itself, or any of the generated code contains this note (I just spent an hour troubleshooting this).
. The thing is, the front page contains enough information to make your own custom font with the provided generator page, there's no hint that reading the javadocs or the wiki is necessary. That is why I got this confusing error. So what I'm proposing is a santity check somewhere to avoid this for other users. For example;
- Add a simple length check in the javascript font library generator at http://android-iconics.mikepenz.com/ for the mapping prefix
- In com.mikepenz.iconics.IconicsregisterFont(ITypeface font) add a simple check e.g.
  if(font.getMappingPrefix().length != 3) throw new IllegalArgumentException("Mapping prefix must be 3 characters long")
. Fair enough.
. Sorry, perhaps I did not explain the issue adequately. It's a single character. The problem arises due to the compiler interpreting the single backslash character as an escaping character (so instead, it sees an escaped single quote character, and then the parenthesis, so a java syntax error is created).
I'm using IcoMoon.
. Try using \u005c for any character and you'll see what I mean! :)
. No - Unicode characters start at \u0000. The "E" you are referring to is just a greater number in the valid range.
. I agree that it should probably be avoided. This is just what our designer decided to use... It has worked in our other apps so there was not a problem until now. There are more characters that could cause trouble, such as \u0027, the single quote character.
.
